elements.content: Flexible bis­(imidazole) linkers incorporating methyl-, ethyl, and isopropyl- groups on imidazole rings were synthesized, and their seven Zn­(II)-coordination polymers, namely, {[Zn2(μ4-ao2btc)­(μ-1,5-bipe)2]­·4DMF} n (1), {[Zn2(μ6-ao2btc)­(μ-1,5-bmeipe)]­·2DMA} n (2), {[Zn2(μ8-ao2btc)­(μ-1,5-beipe)]­·DMA} n (3), {[Zn4(μ8-ao2btc)­(μ-1,5-bisoipe)2]­·2DMF} n (4), {[Zn2(μ4-ao2btc)­(μ-1,6-bih)1.5­(DMA)]­·2DMA} n (5), {[Zn2(μ8-abtc)­(μ-1,6-bmeih)]­·DMF} n (6), and {[Zn2(μ8-ao2btc)­(μ-1,6-beih)]­·DMF} n (7) (ao2btc = dioxygenated form of 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylate, 1,5-bipe: 1,5-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­pentane, 1,5-b­(x)­ipe: 1,5-bis­(2-x-imidazol-1-yl)­pentane (x = methyl-, ethyl-, isopropyl-), 1,6-bih: 1,6-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­hexane, 1,6-b­(x)­ih = 1,6-bis­(2-y-imidazol-1-yl)­hexane (y = methyl-, ethyl-)), were obtained with azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid to investigate the effect of substitute groups of bis­(imidazole) ligands on structural diversity and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, and thermal analyses (TG/DTA). X-ray results demonstrated that complex 1 had a two-dimensional (2D) structure, while the other complexes were three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers. For complexes 1–4, the dimensionality increased with the steric hindrance on imidazole rings. Complexes 2–7 were 3D frameworks with one-dimensional (1D) channels, and their 1D channel sizes decreased with the change of substitute groups from −CH3 to −CH­(CH3)2. For complexes 3, 4, 6, and 7, paddlewheel Zn2(CO2)4 binuclear secondary building units occurred with the increase of steric hindrance of substitute groups on imidazole rings. CO2 adsorption results of the complexes showed that uptake capacities decreased with the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups from methyl- to isopropyl- in channels. Furthermore, photoluminescence and topological properties of the complexes were studied.

elements.content: Seven novel Zn­(II)-coordination polymers with flexible substitute bis­(imidazole) linkers and 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid to investigate the effect of substitute groups of bis­(imidazole) ligands on the structural diversity were obtained and characterized. Paddlewheel Zn2(CO2)4 binuclear secondary building units were observed with the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups from methyl- to isopropyl- on imidazole rings in channels. CO2 adsorption results showed that uptake capacities of complexes were decreased with the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups from methyl- to isopropyl- in channels.

elements.content: In recent years, a great deal of attention has focused on the rational design and construction of coordination polymers owing to their diverse application areas, e.g., gas adsorption/separation, catalyst, luminescence, iodine encapsulation, dye adsorption/degradation, drug delivery, etc., and their fascinating architectures. Up to now, although a large number of coordination polymers have been synthesized and characterized, it has still been a challenge to rationally synthesize targeted structures. There are several factors (organic ligands, metal ions, pH, solvents, temperature) directing the final structures of coordination polymers in the self-assembly process. In the rational design and synthesis of coordination polymers, the selection of the appropriate organic ligand from the above factors is the most important parameter. In the construction of coordination polymers, polycarboxylates (di-, tri-, tetra- carboxylates) have been widely employed as bridging ligands due to their versatile coordination modes. In this study, 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4abtc), easily oxidized to generate mono- and dioxygenated azoxy-structures, can bind to metal ions with four carboxylate groups in diverse coordination modes and is a symmetric rigid ligand which enhances the thermal stability when coordinated to metal ions. Recently, the incorporation of polycarboxylates and ancillary N-donor ligands has become an effective way for construction of coordination polymers with desired structures. Flexible, semiflexible and rigid bis­(imidazole) derivative ligands have been extensively used as auxiliary N-donor ligands for the connection of metal ion in the syntheses of mixed-ligand coordination polymers. Especially, flexible bis­(imidazole) ligands have been widely preferred due to free rotation of imidazole rings around −CH2– groups and have adopted different conformations to connect to metal ions easily. In the literature, although some coordination polymers were synthesized with 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4abtc) and flexible bis­(imidazole) derivatives, there were no systematic investigations with azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid and flexible bis­(imidazole) ligands. Moreover, the systematic study related to the effect of substitute groups of bis­(imidazole) ligands on the final structures of coordination polymers has been rare. In this study, two -methyl, -ethyl, and -isopropyl groups were inserted into the bis­(imidazole) linkers to systematically investigate the effect of substitute groups on structural diversities of coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, a great deal of attention has focused on the rational design and construction of coordination polymers owing to their diverse application areas, e.g., gas adsorption/separation, catalyst, luminescence, iodine encapsulation, dye adsorption/degradation, drug delivery, etc., and their fascinating architectures. Up to now, although a large number of coordination polymers have been synthesized and characterized, it has still been a challenge to rationally synthesize targeted structures. There are several factors (organic ligands, metal ions, pH, solvents, temperature) directing the final structures of coordination polymers in the self-assembly process. In the rational design and synthesis of coordination polymers, the selection of the appropriate organic ligand from the above factors is the most important parameter. In the construction of coordination polymers, polycarboxylates (di-, tri-, tetra- carboxylates) have been widely employed as bridging ligands due to their versatile coordination modes. In this study, 3,3',5,5'-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4abtc), easily oxidized to generate mono- and dioxygenated azoxy-structures, can bind to metal ions with four carboxylate groups in diverse coordination modes and is a symmetric rigid ligand which enhances the thermal stability when coordinated to metal ions. Recently, the incorporation of polycarboxylates and ancillary N-donor ligands has become an effective way for construction of coordination polymers with desired structures. Flexible, semiflexible and rigid bis(imidazole) derivative ligands have been extensively used as auxiliary N-donor ligands for the connection of metal ion in the syntheses of mixed-ligand coordination polymers. Especially, flexible bis(imidazole) ligands have been widely preferred due to free rotation of imidazole rings around -CH2- groups and have adopted different conformations to connect to metal ions easily. In the literature, although some coordination polymers were synthesized with 3,3',5,5'-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4abtc) and flexible bis(imidazole) derivatives, there were no systematic investigations with azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid and flexible bis(imidazole) ligands. Moreover, the systematic study related to the effect of substitute groups of bis(imidazole) ligands on the final structures of coordination polymers has been rare. In this study, two -methyl, -ethyl, and -isopropyl groups were inserted into the bis(imidazole) linkers to systematically investigate the effect of substitute groups on structural diversities of coordination polymers.

elements.content: Taking all the above into account, seven flexible bis­(imidazole) derivative ligands, namely, 1,5-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­pentane (1,5-bipe), 1,5-bis­(2-methylimidazol-1-yl)­pentane (1,5-bmeipe), 1,5-bis­(2-ethylimidazol-1-yl)­pentane (1,5-beipe), 1,5-bis­(2-isopropylimidazol-1-yl)­pentane (1,5-bisoipe), 1,6-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­hexane (1,6-bih), 1,6-bis­(2-methylimidazol-1-yl)­hexane (1,6-bmeih), and 1,6-bis­(2-ethylimidazol-1-yl)­hexane (1,6-beih) were prepared, and serially, their Zn­(II)-coordination polymers, ({[Zn2(μ4-ao2btc)­(μ-1,5-bipe)2]­·4DMF} n (1), {[Zn2(μ6-ao2btc)­(μ-1,5-bmeipe)]­·2DMA} n (2), {[Zn2(μ8-ao2btc)­(μ-1,5-beipe)]­·DMA} n (3), {[Zn4(μ8-ao2btc)­(μ-1,5-bisoipe)2]­·2DMF} n (4), {[Zn2(μ4-ao2btc)­(μ-1,6-bih)1.5­(DMA)]­·2DMA} n (5), {[Zn2(μ8-abtc)­(μ-1,6-bmeih)]­·DMF} n (6), and {[Zn2(μ8-ao2btc)­(μ-1,6-beih)]­·DMF} n (7), were synthesized with 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid to investigate the effect of substitute groups of bis­(imidazole) ligands on the structural diversity. They were structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermal analysis techniques. Furthermore, photoluminescence, topological, and CO2 adsorption properties were studied.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased commercially and were used without further purification. H4abtc, 1,5-bipe, 1,5-bmeipe, 1,6-bih, and 1,6-bmeih ligands were synthesized according to the literature. A Bruker Tensor 27 FT–IR spectrometer was used for IR spectra (using KBr pellets in the range of 400–4000 cm–1). Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were acquired with a PerkinElmer 2400C elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Varian 500 MHz spectrometer using DMSO-d 6. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected by a Rikagu Smartlab X-ray diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 nm) in the range 10–50° 2θ. A PerkinElmer Diamond TG/DTA thermal analyzer was used to record thermal curves with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the static air atmosphere. The photoluminescence spectra of the solid and suspension samples were recorded on a PerkinElmer LS-55 spectrophotometer. Topological analyses were performed using ToposPro software. Sorption isotherms for N2 and CO2 were acquired with Quantachrome Autosorb 1-C device at 77 K and 273, respectively. Diffraction data of 1, 3–7, and 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD and a STOE IPDS diffractometer equipped with MoKα (0.71073 Å), respectively. The structures were solved by SHELXS and refined by full-matrix least-squares on all F2 data using SHELXL in conjunction with the OLEX2 graphical user interface. For all complexes, the anisotropic thermal parameters were refined for non-hydrogen atoms, and hydrogen atoms were calculated and refined with a riding model. The most noticeable features of the determination of the structures for 2–7 are the ratios of the residual electron densities that are slightly different under −1 and +1. These peaks lie in positions that are neither chemically sensible, nor fit to any discernible disorder pattern. One obvious possible cause for such peaks are disorders for 2–7. Molecule drawings were carried out with Mercury program.

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents were purchased commercially and were used without further purification. H4abtc, 1,5-bipe, 1,5-bmeipe, 1,6-bih, and 1,6-bmeih ligands were synthesized according to the literature. A Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrometer was used for IR spectra (using KBr pellets in the range of 400-4000 cm-1). Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were acquired with a PerkinElmer 2400C elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Varian 500 MHz spectrometer using DMSO-d 6. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected by a Rikagu Smartlab X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 nm) in the range 10-50° 2θ. A PerkinElmer Diamond TG/DTA thermal analyzer was used to record thermal curves with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the static air atmosphere. The photoluminescence spectra of the solid and suspension samples were recorded on a PerkinElmer LS-55 spectrophotometer. Topological analyses were performed using ToposPro software. Sorption isotherms for N2 and CO2 were acquired with Quantachrome Autosorb 1-C device at 77 K and 273, respectively. Diffraction data of 1, 3-7, and 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD and a STOE IPDS diffractometer equipped with MoKα (0.71073 Å), respectively. The structures were solved by SHELXS and refined by full-matrix least-squares on all F2 data using SHELXL in conjunction with the OLEX2 graphical user interface. For all complexes, the anisotropic thermal parameters were refined for non-hydrogen atoms, and hydrogen atoms were calculated and refined with a riding model. The most noticeable features of the determination of the structures for 2-7 are the ratios of the residual electron densities that are slightly different under -1 and +1. elements.content: A mixture of 2-ethylimidazole (5.77 g, 60 mmol) or 2-isopropylimidazole (6.61 g, 60 mmol) and NaOH (2.40 g, 60 mmol) was stirred in 30 mL of DMSO at 60 °C until a clear mixture was obtained. Afterward, 1,5-dibromopentane (6.44 g, 28 mmol) was added into the reaction mixture and stirred at 60 °C for 16 h. After the solution was cooled to room temperature, DMSO was evaporated. The crude product was stirred in 100 mL of CH2Cl2 and filtered. The filtration was extracted twice with 200 mL of water. The separated organic phase was filtered over Na2SO4 and evaporated to give a clear yellow oily product.

Syntheses of the Ligands

1,5-Bis(2-ethyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pentane (1,5-beipe) and 1,5-Bis(2-isopropyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pentane (1,5-bisoipe)

A mixture of 2-ethylimidazole (5.77 g, 60 mmol) or 2-isopropylimidazole (6.61 g, 60 mmol) and NaOH (2.40 g, 60 mmol) was stirred in 30 mL of DMSO at 60 °C until a clear mixture was obtained. Afterward, 1,5-dibromopentane (6.44 g, 28 mmol) was added into the reaction mixture and stirred at 60 °C for 16 h. After the solution was cooled to room temperature, DMSO was evaporated. The crude product was stirred in 100 mL of CH2Cl2 and filtered. The filtration was extracted twice with 200 mL of water. The separated organic phase was filtered over Na2SO4 and evaporated to give a clear yellow oily product.

Yield: 0.104 g, 34% (based on H4abtc). Anal. Calcd for C46H60N11O13Zn2: C, 49.96; H, 5.47; N, 13.93%. Found: C, 49.37; H, 5.20; N, 13.12%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3130 m, 2935 m, 2864 w, 1631 vs, 1573 s, 1440 s, 1363 vs, 781 m, 727 m, cm-1.

{[Zn2(μ8-abtc)(μ-1,6-bmeih)]⋅DMF} n  (6) and {[Zn2(μ8-ao2btc)(μ-1,6-beih)]⋅DMF} n  (7)

The procedures for the syntheses of 6 and 7 were similar to that used for 4, except that 1,5-bmeih (0.069 g, 0.279 mmol) for 6 and 1,6-beih (0.076 g, 0.279 mmol) for 7 were used instead of 1,5-bisoipe.

elements.content: For 6; Yield: 0.163 g, 71% (based on H4abtc). Anal. Calcd for C33H35N7O10Zn2: C, 49.27; H, 4.82; N, 12.77%. Found: C, 48.90; H, 4.63; N, 12.20%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3134 w, 3066 w, 2935 w, 2858 w, 1651 vs, 1582 m, 1444 s, 1387 s, 785 m, 721 m, cm–1.

For 7; Yield: 0.193 g, 80% (based on H4abtc). Anal. Calcd for C35H39N7O11Zn2: C, 48.65; H, 4.69; N, 11.56%. Found: C, 49.05; H, 5.10; N, 11.79%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3132 w, 2978 w, 2933 w, 1649 vs, 1504 m, 1442 s, 1383 s, 785 m, 719 m, cm–1.

3,3′,5,5′-Azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid and systematic substitue bis­(imidazole) derivative ligands () were synthesized, and their Zn­(II)-coordination polymers were obtained in acidic medium in similar solvent mixtures. The complexes were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, thermal analysis techniques, and elemental analysis. Elemental analysis results agreed with single crystal X-ray results. IR spectra of the complexes are given in Figure S1. In the IR spectra of complexes 1–7, the weak bands observed between 3134 and 2866 cm–1 are assigned to aromatic and aliphatic ν­(C–H) stretching vibrations, respectively. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups of H4abtc ligand are observed at 1710 and 1278 cm–1, respectively. The asymmetric stretching vibration observed at 1710 cm–1 of H4abtc shifted to lower frequency after conversion to complexes 1–7, indicating the full deprotonation of carboxylate groups of H4abtc. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations for 1–7 appeared in the range 1657–1622 cm–1 and 1387–1346 cm–1, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

3,3',5,5'-Azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid and systematic substitue bis(imidazole) derivative ligands () were synthesized, and their Zn(II)-coordination polymers were obtained in acidic medium in similar solvent mixtures. The complexes were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, thermal analysis techniques, and elemental analysis. Elemental analysis results agreed with single crystal X-ray results. IR spectra of the complexes are given in Figure S1. In the IR spectra of complexes 1-7, the weak bands observed between 3134 and 2866 cm-1 are assigned to aromatic and aliphatic ν(C-H) stretching vibrations, respectively. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups of H4abtc ligand are observed at 1710 and 1278 cm-1, respectively. The asymmetric stretching vibration observed at 1710 cm-1 of H4abtc shifted to lower frequency after conversion to complexes 1-7, indicating the full deprotonation of carboxylate groups of H4abtc. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations for 1-7 appeared in the range 1657-1622 cm-1 and 1387-1346 cm-1, respectively.

elements.content:
The crystal data and the refinement details of complexes are given in and . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Tables S1–S7, respectively.

{[Zn<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>4</sub>-ao<sub>2</sub>btc)­(μ-1,5-bipe)<sub>2</sub>]·4DMF}<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>1</bold>)

The X-ray single crystal structural analysis reveals that complex 1 is a two-dimensonal (2D) ladder-like coordination polymer. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Zn­(II) ion, half ao2btc anion, one 1,5-bipe ligand, and two DMF molecules. Each Zn­(II) ion in 1 exhibits a distorted tetrahedral environment (τ4 = 0.918), composed of two carboxylic O atoms from two different ao2btc anions [Zn1–O1 = 1.9766(15); Zn1–O4i = 1.9863(16) Å] and two N atoms from two different 1,5-bipe ligands [Zn1–N2 = 2.008(2); Zn1–N5ii = 2.017(2) Å], as shown in a. The Zn­(II) ions are bridged by O1 and O4 atoms of ao2btc ligands to generate a 26-membered ring. The combination of 26-membered rings produces 1D chain structures of the complex (Figure S2a). Adjacent 1D chains are linked by nitrogen atoms (N2 and N5) of 1,5-bipe ligands with a Zn···Zn distance of 10.513 Å to generate 2D structures, with the pore dimension of 14.187 × 15.11 Å2 (defined by Zn···Zn distances) (Figure S2b). 2D layers of the complex adopt −AAA– stacking to form a 3D supramolecular network (b). The free void volume of 1 after the removal of DMF molecules is 1110.2 Å3, which represents 38.5% per unit cell volume, according to a calculation performed with PLATON (b). Topologically, complex 1 is (3,4)-connected binodal net with the point symbol of {4.62}2{42.62.82} (c).

{[Zn2(μ4-ao2btc)(μ-1,5-bipe)2]⋅4DMF} n  (1)

The X-ray single crystal structural analysis reveals that complex 1 is a two-dimensonal (2D) ladder-like coordination polymer. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Zn(II) ion, half ao2btc anion, one 1,5-bipe ligand, and two DMF molecules. Each Zn(II) ion in 1 exhibits a distorted tetrahedral environment (τ4 = 0.918), composed of two carboxylic O atoms from two different ao2btc anions [Zn1-O1 = 1.9766(15); Zn1-O4i = 1.9863(16) Å] and two N atoms from two different 1,5-bipe ligands [Zn1-N2 = 2.008(2); Zn1-N5ii = 2.017(2) Å], as shown in a. The Zn(II) ions are bridged by O1 and O4 atoms of ao2btc ligands to generate a 26-membered ring. The combination of 26-membered rings produces 1D chain structures of the complex (Figure S2a). Adjacent 1D chains are linked by nitrogen atoms (N2 and N5) of 1,5-bipe ligands with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 10.513 Å to generate 2D structures, with the pore dimension of 14.187 × 15.11 Å2 (defined by Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances) (Figure S2b). 2D layers of the complex adopt -AAA- stacking to form a 3D supramolecular network (b). The free void volume of 1 after the removal of DMF molecules is 1110.2 Å3, which represents 38.5% per unit cell volume, according to a calculation performed with PLATON (b). Topologically, complex 1 is (3,4)-connected binodal net with the point symbol of {4.62}2{42.62.82} (c).

elements.content: To further examine the influence of the auxiliary ligand which is substituted with the −CH3 group on the imidazole ring on the structure, we used 1,5-bmeipe instead of the 1,5-bipe ligand. When the 1,5-bmeipe ligand was used as an auxiliary ligand, a three-dimensional (3D) framework was obtained. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with the C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of complex 2 contains one Zn­(II) ion, half ao2btc anion, half 1,5-bmeipe ligand, and one DMA molecules. As shown in a, the environment around Zn­(II) ion can be described as a distorted square pyramidal geometry (τ5 = 0.142), in which it is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two ao2btc ligands and one nitrogen atom from 1,5-bmeipe ligand in an equatorial plane and one oxygen atom from ao2btc ligand occupies the axial position. Each ao2btc ligand acts an octadentate ligand in which 3,3′-carboxyl groups display bidentate bridging modes, and 5,5′-carboxyl groups exhibit bidentate chelating modes, connecting to six metal centers. Zn­(II) ions are bridged by 3,3′,5,5′-carboxylate oxygen atoms of the ao2btc ligand to form one-dimensional (1D) double zigzag chains with 28-membered rings (Figure S3a). Adjacent 1D double chains are linked by 3,5′-carboxyl groups of ao2btc with a Zn···Zn distance of 4.158 Å to generate 2D structures (Figure S3b). 2D structures are extended to a 3D porous structure by the coordination of ao2btc ligand (b,c). The free void volume of 2 after the removal of DMA molecules is 1323.7 Å3, which represents 33% per unit cell volume, according to PLATON analysis. Topologically, complex 2 is 3D (3,6)-connected sqc5381 net with the point symbol of {42.6}2{44.66.85} (d).

elements.content: The X-ray single crystal study shows that complexes 3 and 4 have a 3D coordination polymer. The crystallographic analyses reveal that complexes 3 and 4 appear to be very similar. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains two Zn­(II) ion, one ao2btc anion, one 1,5-beipe ligand, and one DMA molecule (a), while the asymmetric unit of 4 contains one Zn­(II) ion, half ao2btc anion, one 1,5-beipe ligand, and one DMF molecule (a). Each Zn­(II) ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four different ao2btc ligands and one nitrogen atom from 1,5-beipe or 1,5-bisoipe ligands, thus showing a distorted square pyramidal geometry (τ5 = 0.0012 for 3). All carboxylate oxygen atoms of four different ao2btc ligands coordinate eight Zn­(II) ions to form a paddle-wheel [Zn2(COO)4] secondary building unit (SBU) with Zn···Zn distances of 3.101 Å for 3 and 3.110 Å for 4. The ao2btc ligand displays μ8-η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination mode with the interisophthalate dihedral angle of 161.95° (through C3–C7–C9–C13) for 3 and 180° (through C3–C7–C7x–C3x) for 4. Paddlewheel type Zn2 clusters are connected together by ao2btc linkers to generate a 3D framework (b and b). 1,5-beipe and 1,5-bisoipe ligands have contributed to the stabilities of the structures by completing the fifth coordination site. The structures have 1D hexagonal channels, with the pore dimensions of approximately 10 × 10 Å2 for 3 and 7.93 × 9.46 Å2 (defined by Zn···Zn distances) for 4 (Figures S4a and S5a). The free void volumes of complexes after the removal of solvent molecules are 740.6 Å3 for 3 and 576.2 Å3 for 4 which represent 19.6% for 3 and 15% for 4 per unit cell volume, according to PLATON analysis. Topologically, complexes are a 3D (3,6)-connected sqc5381 net with the point symbol of {42.6}2{44.66.85} like 2 (Figures S4b and S5b).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 5 with atom numbering scheme is shown in a. X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis demonstrates that complex 5 crystallizes in the triclinic system with the space group of P1̅. The asymmetric unit of 5 consists of two Zn­(II) ions, one ao2btc, one and half bih, and one coordinated DMA and two uncoordinated DMA molecules. Although Zn­(II) centers adopt distorted tetrahedral geometry in the structure, they have different coordination environments. Zn1 atom is coordinated by two carboxylate O atoms from two different ao2btc ligands and two imidazole N atoms from two different 1,6-bih ligands, while Zn2 atom is coordinated by two O atoms from two different ao2btc ligands and one N atom from one 1,6-bih ligand and one N atom from coordinated DMA molecule. Zn­(II) ions are bridged by 3,3′ and 5,5′-carboxylate oxygen atoms of ao2btc ligand as a monodentate to form 2D structure, which are further coordinated to 1,6-bih ligand to generate 3D framework (b). Four ao2btc ligands connect to four Zn­(II) ions to form 52- and 32-membered rings. In complex 5, there are two types of bih ligands which display trans conformations. In 1,6-bih connected to Zn1 center, the two imidazole rings are parallel with a distance of 10.761 Å, while in other 1,6-bih connected to Zn2 center, the two imidazole rings are parallel with a distance of 8.458 Å. According to PLATON analysis, 5 has voids of 590.2 Å3 which represent 24% per unit cell volume. Topologically, complex 5 is 3D 4-nodal 3,4,4,4-connected net with the point symbol of {72.83.10}­{72.8}­{73.83} (c).

elements.content: X-ray analysis studies reveal that complexes 6 and 7 are similar structures (isomorphous). When methyl- and ethyl- substitute (imidazol-1yl)­hexane ligands were used instead of nonsubstitute bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­hexane, {Zn2(CO2)4}-type binuclear SBU based 3D frameworks of 6 and 7 were obtained. Both complexes crystallize in the monoclinic space group C2/c. In 7, the abtc ligand oxidized to dioxygenated ao2btc in reaction medium. As shown in , there are one Zn­(II) ion, half abtc (ao2btc for 7), half neutral ligand, and one DMF molecule in the asymmetric units of 6 and 7. In the complexes, each Zn­(II) ion which has distorted square pyramid geometry is coordinated by four carboxylate O atoms from four abtc ligands and two imidazole N atoms from two different neutral ligands. A pair of Zn­(II) ions are connected by four carboxylate O atoms to generate paddlewheel {Zn2(CO2)4} binuclear SBUs with Zn···Zn distances of 3.058 Å for 6 and 3.066 Å for 7. Each {Zn2(CO2)4} binuclear SBU is connected by four different abtc ligands to form a 3D framework (). Each abtc ligand acts an octadentate ligand in which 3,3′,5,5′-carboxyl groups display bidentate bridging modes to connect to eight metal centers in 6 and 7. In the complexes, two Zn­(II) ions are bridged by neutral ligand and 3,3′-carboxylate oxygen atoms to form 1D hexagonal channels, with the pore dimensions of approximately, 10.343 × 8.206 Å2 for 6, and 10.246 × 8.223 Å2 for 7, respectively (). According to PLATON analysis, the solvent-accessible volumes for 6 and 7 are 23.8% and 20.9, respectively. Topologically, complexes 6 and 7 have 3,6-connected sqc5381 net with the point symbol of {42.6}2{44.66.85} like complexes 2–4.

elements.content: All Zn­(II)-complexes were synthesized about at 95 °C in acidic medium using 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylate as an anionic ligand and a series of methyl-, ethyl-, and isopropyl-substituted bis­(imidazole) derivatives as neutral ligands to investigate the effect of substitute groups on structural diversity. In all complexes, azo-groups of abtc are oxidized to generate dioxygenated forms (ao2btc) except complex 6. The abtc or ao2btc ligands display various coordination modes to connect to Zn­(II) ions (). Complex 1 synthesized with abtc and nonsubstitute 1,5-bipe exhibits 2D structure, while complexes 2–4 obtained with abtc and substitute bis­(imidazole) linkers are 3D frameworks. In the series of non- and substitute-bis­(imidazole-1yl)­pentane, the dimension was increased with the increase of steric hindrance on imidazole rings. Complexes 5–7 synthesized using non- or substitute bis­(imidazol-1yl)­hexane have 3D structures. There is no effect of substitute groups of bis­(imidazole) linkers on the dimensionalities of complexes 5–7. Complexes 2–7 are 3D frameworks with 1D channels, and their 1D channel sizes reduce as alkyl groups change from −CH3 to −CH­(CH3)2. Bis­(imidazole) linkers having a flexible long methylene skeleton tend to display interpenetration or polycatenation. In literature studies using abtc and flexible neutral ligands, {[Zn­(abtc)0.5(bip)]­H2O} n and {[Zn­(abtc)0.5(bib)]­·3H2O} n complexes prepared by using abtc and 1,3-bis­(imidazol-1yl)­propane (bip) or 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1yl)­butane (bib) were synthesized at 165 °C in a mixture of H2O:DMF in basic medium, and they displayed 2-fold interpenetrating and self-penetrating 3D frameworks. Furthermore, [Co3(H2abtc)3(btb)­(H2O)6] n synthesized with bis­(triazol-1-yl)­butane at 120 °C in H2O containing NaOH was a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D pillar-layered framework. Interpenetration or polycatenation was observed in the above complexes prepared by using abtc and flexible bis­(imidazole) linkers in neutral or basic mediums at high temperature. Although flexible bis­(imidazole) linkers were utilized in this study, complexes 1–7 which were synthesized at low temperature and acidic medium did not show interpenetration or polycatenation. Hence, reaction conditions are important to control the final structures of coordination polymers. Complexes 1–4 and 6, 7 had a binodal net, while complex 5 exhibited a 4-nodal 3,4,4,4-connected net. Complexes 2–4 and 6, 7 exhibited a 3,6-connected 3D sqc5381 net with the point symbol of {42.6}2{44.66.85}. Moreover, as seen in the crystal section, complexes displayed paddlewheel Zn2(CO2)4 binuclear SBUs with the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups from methyl- to isopropyl- on imidazole rings in channels. Hence, substitute bis­(imidazole) linkers having steric hindrance in channels can be used to obtain paddlewheel SBUs in the synthesis of coordination polymers with the abtc ligand. Moreover, there are weak C–H···O interactions between the encapsulated solvent molecules and frameworks in all complexes.

Structural Comparison

All Zn(II)-complexes were synthesized about at 95 °C in acidic medium using 3,3',5,5'-azobenzenetetracarboxylate as an anionic ligand and a series of methyl-, ethyl-, and isopropyl-substituted bis(imidazole) derivatives as neutral ligands to investigate the effect of substitute groups on structural diversity. In all complexes, azo-groups of abtc are oxidized to generate dioxygenated forms (ao2btc) except complex 6. The abtc or ao2btc ligands display various coordination modes to connect to Zn(II) ions (). Complex 1 synthesized with abtc and nonsubstitute 1,5-bipe exhibits 2D structure, while complexes 2-4 obtained with abtc and substitute bis(imidazole) linkers are 3D frameworks. In the series of non- and substitute-bis(imidazole-1yl)pentane, the dimension was increased with the increase of steric hindrance on imidazole rings. Complexes 5-7 synthesized using non- or substitute bis(imidazol-1yl)hexane have 3D structures. There is no effect of substitute groups of bis(imidazole) linkers on the dimensionalities of complexes 5-7. Complexes 2-7 are 3D frameworks with 1D channels, and their 1D channel sizes reduce as alkyl groups change from -CH3 to -CH(CH3)2. Bis(imidazole) linkers having a flexible long methylene skeleton tend to display interpenetration or polycatenation. In literature studies using abtc and flexible neutral ligands, {[Zn(abtc)0.5(bip)]H2O} n  and {[Zn(abtc)0.5(bib)]⋅3H2O} n  complexes prepared by using abtc and 1,3-bis(imidazol-1yl)propane (bip) or 1,4-bis(imidazol-1yl)butane (bib) were synthesized at 165 °C in a mixture of H2O:DMF in basic medium, and they displayed 2-fold interpenetrating and self-penetrating 3D frameworks. Furthermore, [Co3(H2abtc)3(btb)(H2O)6] n  synthesized with bis(triazol-1-yl)butane at 120 °C in H2O containing NaOH was a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D pillar-layered framework. Interpenetration or polycatenation was observed in the above complexes prepared by using abtc and flexible bis(imidazole) linkers in neutral or basic mediums at high temperature. Although flexible bis(imidazole) linkers were utilized in this study, complexes 1-7 which were synthesized at low temperature and acidic medium did not show interpenetration or polycatenation. Hence, reaction conditions are important to control the final structures of coordination polymers. Complexes 1-4 and 6, 7 had a binodal net, while complex 5 exhibited a 4-nodal 3,4,4,4-connected net. Complexes 2-4 and 6, 7 exhibited a 3,6-connected 3D sqc5381 net with the point symbol of {42.6}2{44.66.85}. Moreover, as seen in the crystal section, complexes displayed paddlewheel Zn2(CO2)4 binuclear SBUs with the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups from methyl- to isopropyl- on imidazole rings in channels. Hence, substitute bis(imidazole) linkers having steric hindrance in channels can be used to obtain paddlewheel SBUs in the synthesis of coordination polymers with the abtc ligand. Moreover, there are weak C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions between the encapsulated solvent molecules and frameworks in all complexes.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed to check the phase purity of the bulk materials. (Figure S6). PXRD patterns of the complexes are consistent with the simulated patterns obtained from their single-crystal structures, indicating the phase purities of the complexes. PXRD patterns of complexes were recorded three months later, and PXRD patterns of the complexes have still been good agreement with the simulated patterns obtained from their single-crystal structures. Therefore, the complexes showed stability at room temperature in air.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction and Thermal Analysis Results

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed to check the phase purity of the bulk materials. (Figure S6). PXRD patterns of the complexes are consistent with the simulated patterns obtained from their single-crystal structures, indicating the phase purities of the complexes. PXRD patterns of complexes were recorded three months later, and PXRD patterns of the complexes have still been good agreement with the simulated patterns obtained from their single-crystal structures. Therefore, the complexes showed stability at room temperature in air.

elements.content: The thermal behaviors and stabilities of complexes 1–7 were investigated by thermal analysis techniques in a static air atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the temperature range 30–700 °C (Figures S7–13). For complexes 1 and 4, the first weight losses of 24.93% in the temperature range of 55–200 °C for 1 and 8.6% in the temperature range of 66–192 °C correspond to removal of DMF molecules, respectively (calcd.: 7.98% for 1, calcd.: 7.08% for 4). After these steps, complexes 1 and 4 are stable up to 299 and 323 °C, respectively. For complexes 2 and 3, the weight losses of 20.74% from 38 to 148 °C and 10% from 66 to 206 °C correspond to the release of DMA molecules, respectively (calcd.: 18.86% for 2 and calcd.: 10.07% for 3). After the removal of DMA molecules, complexes 2 and 3 are stable up to 243 and 334 °C, respectively. For 5–7, the first weight losses correspond to removal of uncoordinated DMA and DMF molecules placed in pores (obsd.: 14.80%, calcd.: 15.77% for 5; obsd.: 13.40%, calcd.: 13.36% for 6; obsd.: 11.33%, calcd.: 11.71% for 7). For all complexes, on further heating, frameworks are decomposed with exothermic picks. The final residual products of complexes 1–7 are possible ZnO (obsd.: 14.69%, calcd.: 13.30% for 1; obsd.: 9.67%, calcd.: 8.77% for 2; obsd.: 18.76%, calcd.: 18.74% for 3; obsd.: 16.29%, calcd.: 15.69% for 4; obsd.: 13.05%, calcd.: 14.66% for 5; obsd.: 18.39%, calcd.: 19.74% for 6; obsd.: 18.69%, calcd.: 18.74% for 7).
elements.clean_text: The thermal behaviors and stabilities of complexes 1-7 were investigated by thermal analysis techniques in a static air atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the temperature range 30-700 °C (Figures S7-13). After these steps, complexes 1 and 4 are stable up to 299 and 323 °C, respectively. For complexes 2 and 3, the weight losses of 20.74% from 38 to 148 °C and 10% from 66 to 206 °C correspond to the release of DMA molecules, respectively (calcd.: 18.86% for 2 and calcd.: 10.07% for 3). After the removal of DMA molecules, complexes 2 and 3 are stable up to 243 and 334 °C, respectively. For 5-7, the first weight losses correspond to removal of uncoordinated DMA and DMF molecules placed in pores (obsd.: 14.80%, calcd.: 15.77% for 5; obsd.: 13.40%, calcd.: 13.36% for 6; obsd.: 11.33%, calcd.: 11.71% for 7). elements.content: As seen from the crystal structures of synthesized complexes, pores with one-dimensional channels encouraged us to perform gas sorption measurements. Prior to the gas adsorption measurements, the complexes were immersed in methanol for 4 days (MetOH was changed with a new one for every day) at room temperature. After that, they were heated to 100 °C for 1 day for full activation under a vacuum to obtain complexes 1a–7a. After activation, PXRD patterns of the activated complexes 1a–7a were similar to as-synthesized PXRD patterns of complexes 1–7 except 2. For 2, the PXRD pattern after activation shows that framework loses crystallinity and may be collapsed or partially decomposed with the removal of solvent molecules in the pores. PXRD patterns of 1a and 3a–7a demonstrate that frameworks are robust after activation. Hence, gas adsorption properties of all complexes except 2 were studied.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Studies

As seen from the crystal structures of synthesized complexes, pores with one-dimensional channels encouraged us to perform gas sorption measurements. Prior to the gas adsorption measurements, the complexes were immersed in methanol for 4 days (MetOH was changed with a new one for every day) at room temperature. After that, they were heated to 100 °C for 1 day for full activation under a vacuum to obtain complexes 1a-7a. After activation, PXRD patterns of the activated complexes 1a-7a were similar to as-synthesized PXRD patterns of complexes 1-7 except 2. For 2, the PXRD pattern after activation shows that framework loses crystallinity and may be collapsed or partially decomposed with the removal of solvent molecules in the pores. PXRD patterns of 1a and 3a-7a demonstrate that frameworks are robust after activation. Hence, gas adsorption properties of all complexes except 2 were studied.

elements.content: N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated complexes were recorded at 77 K and 1.0 bar. BET surface areas are 172.90 m2/g for 1a, 159.0 m2/g for 3a, 100.84 m2/g for 4a, 7.33 m2/g for 5a, 434.43 m2/g for 6a, and 411 m2/g for 7a, respectively. When compared to BET values of complexes which had similar SBU structures, for 3a and 4a and for 6a and 7a, surface areas decreased with the increase of length of substitute groups (or steric hindrance) on imidazole rings in channels.

elements.content: CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms for complexes all complexes except 2 were recorded volumetrically at 273 K and 1.0 bar (). The CO2 adsorption measurements of the complexes exhibit type-I isotherms with the characteristic of microporous structures. Desorption isotherm of complex 7a displays a significant hysteresis loop which demonstrates a small of mesoporosity. The CO2 uptake capacities are 21.24 (4.17%) for 1a, 47.64 (9.36%) for 3a, 28.71 (5.64%) for 4a, 15.29 cm3/g (3.0%) for 5a, 42.85 (8.42%) for 6a, and 32.52 cm3/g (6.39%) for 7a, respectively. As seen from the crystal section, complexes 3 and 4 have similar bis­(imidazole) linkers containing a pentane chain. Only, substitute groups (ethyl- and isopropyl-) on imidazole rings are different. According to PLATON analysis, the solvent-accessible volume of complex 4 is lower than that of complex 3 because of the increase of steric hindrance on imidazole rings in channels. CO2 adsorption values of complexes 3 and 4 confirm the PLATON analysis results. Again, the similar results are observed for complexes 6 and 7. CO2 uptake capacity of complex 7 is lower than complex 6 due to the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups from methyl- to ethyl- in channels. Complexes 3a and 6a have the highest CO2 adsorption values in the other complexes. Moreover, CO2 adsorption values of complexes 3a and 6a are higher than some metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), like MOF-5 (6.2%), MOF-602 (5.0%), and SNU-15 (7.0%) at 273 K and 1 bar.

elements.content: The solid state photoluminescence spectra of free ligand H4abtc and complexes 1–7 were obtained under the same conditions at room temperature ( and ). The emission bands of free ligand H4abtc were observed at 410, 420, 463, 487, and 532 nm upon excitation at 344 nm. These emissions can be assigned to π* → n or π* → π transitions of H4abtc. As seen in and , complexes 1–7 and H4abtc have similar emissions. Complexes 1–7 displayed emissions at 407, 419, 463, and 486 nm (1), 408, 421, 463, and 486 nm (2), 406, 421, 463, and 487 nm (3), 407, 420, 463, and 486 nm (4), 406, 421, 463, and 487 (5), 399, 463, and 487 (6) and 405, 420, 462, and 487 (7) upon excitation at 344 nm, respectively. The emissions of as-synthesized complexes are neither ligand to metal charge transfer nor metal to ligand charge transfer since reduction or oxidation of Zn­(II) ions is difficult owing to d10 configurations of them. Therefore, the emissions of complexes 1–7 can be attributed to intraligand transitions of H4abtc.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The solid state photoluminescence spectra of free ligand H4abtc and complexes 1-7 were obtained under the same conditions at room temperature ( and ). The emission bands of free ligand H4abtc were observed at 410, 420, 463, 487, and 532 nm upon excitation at 344 nm. These emissions can be assigned to π* → n or π* → π transitions of H4abtc. As seen in  and , complexes 1-7 and H4abtc have similar emissions. Complexes 1-7 displayed emissions at 407, 419, 463, and 486 nm (1), 408, 421, 463, and 486 nm (2), 406, 421, 463, and 487 nm (3), 407, 420, 463, and 486 nm (4), 406, 421, 463, and 487 (5), 399, 463, and 487 (6) and 405, 420, 462, and 487 (7) upon excitation at 344 nm, respectively. The emissions of as-synthesized complexes are neither ligand to metal charge transfer nor metal to ligand charge transfer since reduction or oxidation of Zn(II) ions is difficult owing to d10 configurations of them. Therefore, the emissions of complexes 1-7 can be attributed to intraligand transitions of H4abtc.

elements.content: Moreover, in order to determine photoluminescence properties of as-synthesized complexes in different organic solvents (DMF, MetOH, and CH2Cl2), solvent-dependent photoluminescence studies were carried out. Before the measurements, the complexes (4.0 mg) were finely ground and immersed in solvents (3.0 mL) and then stirred for 24 h to obtain suspensions. The photoluminescence spectra of as-synthesized complexes dispersed in organic solvents were recorded under the same conditions with the solid state photoluminescence spectra (Figures S14–S16). As seen in Figure S14–S16, the emissions of the complexes dispersed in organic solvents are similar to those of the solid-state samples. The shifts in the wavelengths are observed, and the emission intensities for the complexes dispersed in different organic solvents are different due to the solvent effect. The emission intensities of the complexes dispersed in organic solvents increased with the decrease of polarities of solvents. Furthermore, for all complexes, in CH2Cl2 solvent, the intensity of emission peaks at about 408 nm increased.

The shifts in the wavelengths are observed, and the emission intensities for the complexes dispersed in different organic solvents are different due to the solvent effect. The emission intensities of the complexes dispersed in organic solvents increased with the decrease of polarities of solvents. Furthermore, for all complexes, in CH2Cl2 solvent, the intensity of emission peaks at about 408 nm increased.

elements.content: Flexible bis­(imidazole) linkers including -methyl, -ethyl, and -isopropyl groups on imidazole rings were prepared, and serially, their seven 2D and 3D Zn­(II)-coordination polymers were synthesized with abtc ligand to determine the effect of substitute groups on imidazole rings of bis­(imidazole) ligands. Complexes 2–7 were 3D frameworks with 1D channels, while complex 1 displayed 2D structure. Dimensionality increased with the increase of steric hindrance on imidazole rings for complexes 1–4. 1D channel sizes of 3D frameworks decreased when alkyl groups were changed from −CH3 to −CH­(CH3)2 on imidazole rings. This study can provide a promising way to obtain paddlewheel Zn2(CO2)4 binuclear SBUs with the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups on imidazole rings in channels with abtc ligand. CO2 adsorption results showed that CO2 uptake capacities of the complexes decreased with the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups in channels. Furthermore, photoluminescence properties of complexes 1–7 were due to intraligand transitions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Flexible bis(imidazole) linkers including -methyl, -ethyl, and -isopropyl groups on imidazole rings were prepared, and serially, their seven 2D and 3D Zn(II)-coordination polymers were synthesized with abtc ligand to determine the effect of substitute groups on imidazole rings of bis(imidazole) ligands. Complexes 2-7 were 3D frameworks with 1D channels, while complex 1 displayed 2D structure. Dimensionality increased with the increase of steric hindrance on imidazole rings for complexes 1-4. 1D channel sizes of 3D frameworks decreased when alkyl groups were changed from -CH3 to -CH(CH3)2 on imidazole rings. This study can provide a promising way to obtain paddlewheel Zn2(CO2)4 binuclear SBUs with the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups on imidazole rings in channels with abtc ligand. CO2 adsorption results showed that CO2 uptake capacities of the complexes decreased with the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups in channels. Furthermore, photoluminescence properties of complexes 1-7 were due to intraligand transitions.

{[Zn2(μ4-ao2btc)(μ-1,5-bipe)2]⋅4DMF} n  (1)

A mixture of H4abtc (0.1 g, 0.279 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.166 g, 0.558 mmol), and 1,5-bipe (0.056 g, 0.279 mmol) was stirred at 50 °C in DMF (10 mL) for 30 min. Then, HNO3 (6.0 M) was added into the mixture to obtain a clear solution. The clear solution was placed in a vial (25 mL) and heated at 95 °C for 3 days to obtain yellow crystals. Yield: 0.095 g, 56% (based on H4abtc). Anal. Calcd for C25H33N7O7Zn: C, 49.31; H, 5.46; N, 16.10%. Found: C, 49.28; H, 5.83; N, 16.24%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3122 w, 3056 w, 2926 w, 1659 vs, 1633 vs, 1576 m, 1437 m, 1346 vs, 777 s, 746 m, cm-1.

A mixture of H4abtc (0.1 g, 0.279 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.166 g, 0.558 mmol), and 1,5-bmeipe (0.064 g, 0.279 mmol) (for 2) or 1,5-beipe (0.073 g, 0.279 mmol) (for 3) was stirred at 50 °C in the mixture of DMA:H2O (10:2, v:v) for 30 min. After, HNO3 (6.0 M) was added into the mixture until clear solution was obtained. The resulting solution was placed in a vial (25 mL) and heated at 95 °C for 2 days to obtain yellow crystals.

For 2; Yield: 0.182 g, 71% (based on H4abtc). Anal. Calcd for C37H44N8O12Zn2: C, 48.12; H, 4.80; N, 12.13%. Found: C, 48.69; H, 4.45; N, 12.91%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3041 w, 2935 m, 2866 m, 1670 s, 1622 vs, 1577 s, 1437 m, 1392 s, 1354 s, 781 m, 717 m, cm-1.

For 3; Yield: 0.186 g, 77% (based on H4abtc). Anal. Calcd for C35H39N7O11Zn2: C, 48.63; H, 4.55; N, 11.34%. Found: C, 48.90; H, 5.08; N, 11.75%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3128 w, 2974 w, 2933 w, 1654 vs, 1502 m, 1446 s, 1384 vs, 785 m, 717 s, cm-1.

{[Zn4(μ8-ao2btc)(μ-1,5-bisoipe)2]⋅2DMF} n  (4)

A mixture of H4abtc (0.1 g, 0.279 mmol), ZnCl2 (0.076 g, 0.558 mmol), and 1,5-bisoipe (0.080 g, 0.279 mmol) was stirred at 50 °C in the mixture of DMF:H2O (10:2, v:v) for 30 min. After, HNO3 (6.0 M, 3 drops) was added into the mixture. The clear solution was placed in a vial (25 mL) and heated at 100 °C for 2 days to obtain orange crystals. {[Zn2(μ4-ao2btc)(μ-1,6-bih)1.5(DMA)]⋅2DMA} n  (5)

The synthetic procedure of 5 was similar to that of 2, except that 1,6-bih (0.061 g, 0.279 mmol) was used instead of 1,5-beipe. After 3 days, yellow crystals of 5 were obtained. The crystal data and the refinement details of complexes are given in and . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Tables S1–S7, respectively.

{[Zn<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>4</sub>-ao<sub>2</sub>btc)­(μ-1,5-bipe)<sub>2</sub>]·4DMF}<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>1</bold>)

The X-ray single crystal structural analysis reveals that complex 1 is a two-dimensonal (2D) ladder-like coordination polymer. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Zn­(II) ion, half ao2btc anion, one 1,5-bipe ligand, and two DMF molecules. Each Zn­(II) ion in 1 exhibits a distorted tetrahedral environment (τ4 = 0.918), composed of two carboxylic O atoms from two different ao2btc anions [Zn1–O1 = 1.9766(15); Zn1–O4i = 1.9863(16) Å] and two N atoms from two different 1,5-bipe ligands [Zn1–N2 = 2.008(2); Zn1–N5ii = 2.017(2) Å], as shown in a. The Zn­(II) ions are bridged by O1 and O4 atoms of ao2btc ligands to generate a 26-membered ring. The combination of 26-membered rings produces 1D chain structures of the complex (Figure S2a). Adjacent 1D chains are linked by nitrogen atoms (N2 and N5) of 1,5-bipe ligands with a Zn···Zn distance of 10.513 Å to generate 2D structures, with the pore dimension of 14.187 × 15.11 Å2 (defined by Zn···Zn distances) (Figure S2b). 2D layers of the complex adopt −AAA– stacking to form a 3D supramolecular network (b). The free void volume of 1 after the removal of DMF molecules is 1110.2 Å3, which represents 38.5% per unit cell volume, according to a calculation performed with PLATON (b). Topologically, complex 1 is (3,4)-connected binodal net with the point symbol of {4.62}2{42.62.82} (c).

{[Zn<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>6</sub>-ao<sub>2</sub>btc)­(μ-1,5-bmeipe)]·2DMA}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

To further examine the influence of the auxiliary ligand which is substituted with the −CH3 group on the imidazole ring on the structure, we used 1,5-bmeipe instead of the 1,5-bipe ligand. When the 1,5-bmeipe ligand was used as an auxiliary ligand, a three-dimensional (3D) framework was obtained. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with the C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of complex 2 contains one Zn­(II) ion, half ao2btc anion, half 1,5-bmeipe ligand, and one DMA molecules. As shown in a, the environment around Zn­(II) ion can be described as a distorted square pyramidal geometry (τ5 = 0.142), in which it is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two ao2btc ligands and one nitrogen atom from 1,5-bmeipe ligand in an equatorial plane and one oxygen atom from ao2btc ligand occupies the axial position. Each ao2btc ligand acts an octadentate ligand in which 3,3′-carboxyl groups display bidentate bridging modes, and 5,5′-carboxyl groups exhibit bidentate chelating modes, connecting to six metal centers. Zn­(II) ions are bridged by 3,3′,5,5′-carboxylate oxygen atoms of the ao2btc ligand to form one-dimensional (1D) double zigzag chains with 28-membered rings (Figure S3a). Adjacent 1D double chains are linked by 3,5′-carboxyl groups of ao2btc with a Zn···Zn distance of 4.158 Å to generate 2D structures (Figure S3b). 2D structures are extended to a 3D porous structure by the coordination of ao2btc ligand (b,c). The free void volume of 2 after the removal of DMA molecules is 1323.7 Å3, which represents 33% per unit cell volume, according to PLATON analysis. Topologically, complex 2 is 3D (3,6)-connected sqc5381 net with the point symbol of {42.6}2{44.66.85} (d).

{[Zn<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>8</sub>-abtc)­(μ-1,6-bmeih)]·DMF}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (6) and {[Zn<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>8</sub>-ao<sub>2</sub>btc)­(μ-1,6-beih)]­·DMF}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>7</bold>)

X-ray analysis studies reveal that complexes 6 and 7 are similar structures (isomorphous). When methyl- and ethyl- substitute (imidazol-1yl)­hexane ligands were used instead of nonsubstitute bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­hexane, {Zn2(CO2)4}-type binuclear SBU based 3D frameworks of 6 and 7 were obtained. Both complexes crystallize in the monoclinic space group C2/c. In 7, the abtc ligand oxidized to dioxygenated ao2btc in reaction medium. As shown in , there are one Zn­(II) ion, half abtc (ao2btc for 7), half neutral ligand, and one DMF molecule in the asymmetric units of 6 and 7. In the complexes, each Zn­(II) ion which has distorted square pyramid geometry is coordinated by four carboxylate O atoms from four abtc ligands and two imidazole N atoms from two different neutral ligands. A pair of Zn­(II) ions are connected by four carboxylate O atoms to generate paddlewheel {Zn2(CO2)4} binuclear SBUs with Zn···Zn distances of 3.058 Å for 6 and 3.066 Å for 7. Each {Zn2(CO2)4} binuclear SBU is connected by four different abtc ligands to form a 3D framework (). Each abtc ligand acts an octadentate ligand in which 3,3′,5,5′-carboxyl groups display bidentate bridging modes to connect to eight metal centers in 6 and 7. In the complexes, two Zn­(II) ions are bridged by neutral ligand and 3,3′-carboxylate oxygen atoms to form 1D hexagonal channels, with the pore dimensions of approximately, 10.343 × 8.206 Å2 for 6, and 10.246 × 8.223 Å2 for 7, respectively (). According to PLATON analysis, the solvent-accessible volumes for 6 and 7 are 23.8% and 20.9, respectively. Topologically, complexes 6 and 7 have 3,6-connected sqc5381 net with the point symbol of {42.6}2{44.66.85} like complexes 2–4.

The thermal behaviors and stabilities of complexes 1–7 were investigated by thermal analysis techniques in a static air atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the temperature range 30–700 °C (Figures S7–13). For complexes 1 and 4, the first weight losses of 24.93% in the temperature range of 55–200 °C for 1 and 8.6% in the temperature range of 66–192 °C correspond to removal of DMF molecules, respectively (calcd.: 7.98% for 1, calcd.: 7.08% for 4). After these steps, complexes 1 and 4 are stable up to 299 and 323 °C, respectively. For complexes 2 and 3, the weight losses of 20.74% from 38 to 148 °C and 10% from 66 to 206 °C correspond to the release of DMA molecules, respectively (calcd.: 18.86% for 2 and calcd.: 10.07% for 3). After the removal of DMA molecules, complexes 2 and 3 are stable up to 243 and 334 °C, respectively. For 5–7, the first weight losses correspond to removal of uncoordinated DMA and DMF molecules placed in pores (obsd.: 14.80%, calcd.: 15.77% for 5; obsd.: 13.40%, calcd.: 13.36% for 6; obsd.: 11.33%, calcd.: 11.71% for 7). For all complexes, on further heating, frameworks are decomposed with exothermic picks. The final residual products of complexes 1–7 are possible ZnO (obsd.: 14.69%, calcd.: 13.30% for 1; obsd.: 9.67%, calcd.: 8.77% for 2; obsd.: 18.76%, calcd.: 18.74% for 3; obsd.: 16.29%, calcd.: 15.69% for 4; obsd.: 13.05%, calcd.: 14.66% for 5; obsd.: 18.39%, calcd.: 19.74% for 6; obsd.: 18.69%, calcd.: 18.74% for 7).

N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated complexes were recorded at 77 K and 1.0 bar. BET surface areas are 172.90 m2/g for 1a, 159.0 m2/g for 3a, 100.84 m2/g for 4a, 7.33 m2/g for 5a, 434.43 m2/g for 6a, and 411 m2/g for 7a, respectively. When compared to BET values of complexes which had similar SBU structures, for 3a and 4a and for 6a and 7a, surface areas decreased with the increase of length of substitute groups (or steric hindrance) on imidazole rings in channels.

CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms for complexes all complexes except 2 were recorded volumetrically at 273 K and 1.0 bar (). The CO2 adsorption measurements of the complexes exhibit type-I isotherms with the characteristic of microporous structures. Desorption isotherm of complex 7a displays a significant hysteresis loop which demonstrates a small of mesoporosity. The CO2 uptake capacities are 21.24 (4.17%) for 1a, 47.64 (9.36%) for 3a, 28.71 (5.64%) for 4a, 15.29 cm3/g (3.0%) for 5a, 42.85 (8.42%) for 6a, and 32.52 cm3/g (6.39%) for 7a, respectively. As seen from the crystal section, complexes 3 and 4 have similar bis­(imidazole) linkers containing a pentane chain. Only, substitute groups (ethyl- and isopropyl-) on imidazole rings are different. According to PLATON analysis, the solvent-accessible volume of complex 4 is lower than that of complex 3 because of the increase of steric hindrance on imidazole rings in channels. CO2 adsorption values of complexes 3 and 4 confirm the PLATON analysis results. Again, the similar results are observed for complexes 6 and 7. CO2 uptake capacity of complex 7 is lower than complex 6 due to the increase of length of substitute alkyl groups from methyl- to ethyl- in channels. Complexes 3a and 6a have the highest CO2 adsorption values in the other complexes. Moreover, CO2 adsorption values of complexes 3a and 6a are higher than some metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), like MOF-5 (6.2%), MOF-602 (5.0%), and SNU-15 (7.0%) at 273 K and 1 bar.

cln_elements.content: The solid state photoluminescence spectra of free ligand H4abtc and complexes 1–7 were obtained under the same conditions at room temperature ( and ). The emission bands of free ligand H4abtc were observed at 410, 420, 463, 487, and 532 nm upon excitation at 344 nm. These emissions can be assigned to π* → n or π* → π transitions of H4abtc. As seen in and , complexes 1–7 and H4abtc have similar emissions. Complexes 1–7 displayed emissions at 407, 419, 463, and 486 nm (1), 408, 421, 463, and 486 nm (2), 406, 421, 463, and 487 nm (3), 407, 420, 463, and 486 nm (4), 406, 421, 463, and 487 (5), 399, 463, and 487 (6) and 405, 420, 462, and 487 (7) upon excitation at 344 nm, respectively. The emissions of as-synthesized complexes are neither ligand to metal charge transfer nor metal to ligand charge transfer since reduction or oxidation of Zn­(II) ions is difficult owing to d10 configurations of them. Therefore, the emissions of complexes 1–7 can be attributed to intraligand transitions of H4abtc.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The solid state photoluminescence spectra of free ligand H4abtc and complexes 1-7 were obtained under the same conditions at room temperature ( and ). The emission bands of free ligand H4abtc were observed at 410, 420, 463, 487, and 532 nm upon excitation at 344 nm. These emissions can be assigned to π* → n or π* → π transitions of H4abtc. As seen in  and , complexes 1-7 and H4abtc have similar emissions. Complexes 1-7 displayed emissions at 407, 419, 463, and 486 nm (1), 408, 421, 463, and 486 nm (2), 406, 421, 463, and 487 nm (3), 407, 420, 463, and 486 nm (4), 406, 421, 463, and 487 (5), 399, 463, and 487 (6) and 405, 420, 462, and 487 (7) upon excitation at 344 nm, respectively. The emissions of as-synthesized complexes are neither ligand to metal charge transfer nor metal to ligand charge transfer since reduction or oxidation of Zn(II) ions is difficult owing to d10 configurations of them. Therefore, the emissions of complexes 1-7 can be attributed to intraligand transitions of H4abtc.
